                Getty

            By 
Gabriel Debenedetti

11/16/15 06:59 PM EST
Mired in third place and badly trailing his Democratic rivals in fundraising, Martin O’Malley's campaign is shifting staff away from its Baltimore headquarters in an attempt to bolster its operations in the early-voting states — and Iowa in particular.
“After the governor’s strong debate performance in Iowa on Saturday night, we’re shifting more resources and staff to Iowa and the other early states,” confirmed spokeswoman Haley Morris, after MSNBC first reported the move. “We have always run a lean campaign and will continue to do so. We are pursuing matching funds and will compete vigorously for the nomination."
Story Continued Below
The former Maryland governor, who sits at around 3 percent in Iowa according to the Real Clear Politics polling average, needs to vastly improve his numbers in order to gain delegates coming out of the Iowa caucuses. But he trails Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders by large margins, leading many Democrats to question his viability in the state, and also nationally.
The campaign has been struggling to raise money in a field that includes the well-funded Clinton and Sanders campaigns. It raised just under $1.3 million in the third quarter while spending $1.8 million — and it was carrying over $20,000 in debt by the beginning of October.
The move to shift resources comes shortly after a debate performance that was widely seen as O’Malley’s best so far. He recently abandoned his reluctance to attack Clinton and Sanders, earning him more headlines and attention.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
title: O'Malley campaign shifts staff from headquarters
